definitions: catch or take possession of something or someone that had escaped or been lost
bring back or experience again a feeling, quality, or situation from the past
examples: Police managed to recapture the escaped prisoner after three days
The army worked hard to recapture the territory lost in battle
The movie perfectly recaptures the atmosphere of 1950s America
She tried to recapture the happiness of her childhood summers

definitions: melt down metal and pour it into a new mold to create a different shape
present or organize something in a different way or give it a new form
examples: The broken bell was recast into a memorial statue
Workers will recast the damaged bronze sculpture next month
The director decided to recast the movie with younger actors
She recast her novel as a screenplay for television

definitions: move back or away from a previous position gradually over time
gradually become weaker, smaller, or less noticeable until it disappears
examples: The flood waters slowly receded after days of heavy rain
His hairline has been receding since his early thirties
The pain in her shoulder finally receded after taking medicine
Memories of the accident gradually receded as years passed

definitions: stamp or sign a document to show that something has been received officially
examples: Please receipt this delivery form to confirm you got the package
The warehouse manager receipted all incoming shipments before noon

definitions: put electrical power back into a battery or device by connecting it to electricity
rest and regain physical or mental energy after being tired or stressed
examples: Don't forget to recharge your phone before the long trip
The solar panels recharge the backup batteries during sunny days
She took a vacation to recharge after months of hard work
A good night's sleep helps recharge your body and mind

definitions: respond to a gesture or action by doing something similar in return
move backward and forward in a straight line repeatedly like machine parts
examples: She reciprocated his kindness by helping him move apartments
If someone smiles at you, it's polite to reciprocate
The piston reciprocates inside the engine cylinder thousands of times
The saw blade reciprocates rapidly to cut through thick wood

definitions: speak aloud a piece of writing or information that you have memorized
say a list of things in order one after another
examples: The students had to recite poetry in front of the class
She can recite the entire speech without looking at notes
The witness recited the events exactly as they had happened
He recited all the state capitals in alphabetical order

definitions: work out the total number or amount of something by counting or calculating
think or suppose something is true based on your judgment or opinion
examples: The accountant reckoned the total cost of the project carefully
They reckoned the distance to be about fifty miles
I reckon it will rain later looking at those dark clouds
Most people reckon he's the best player on the team

definitions: get back something that belonged to you or that you have a right to
make land suitable for use by draining water or improving poor soil
examples: You can reclaim your luggage at the airport information desk
The family went to court to reclaim their ancestral property
Farmers reclaimed the swampland by building drainage systems
The Dutch reclaimed huge areas of land from the sea

definitions: know who someone is or what something is because you have seen or experienced them before
accept officially that something exists or is true or that someone has achieved something
examples: I didn't recognise her with her new haircut and glasses
The dog recognised its owner's voice from across the park
The university recognised her achievements with an honorary degree
Many countries refuse to recognise the new government

definitions: move back suddenly and quickly because something has frightened or shocked you
react with strong dislike or fear to something unpleasant or shocking
examples: She recoiled when the snake moved toward her
The gun recoiled sharply when he pulled the trigger
He recoiled at the thought of eating raw fish
Most people recoil from violence in any form

definitions: remember something from the past by thinking about it carefully and deliberately
examples: She tried to recollect what had happened at the party
I can't recollect meeting him before, though he says we met

definitions: join or mix things together again after they have been separated into parts
examples: Scientists can recombine DNA from different organisms in the lab
The separated ingredients will recombine when you heat the mixture

definitions: give someone money or something else to make up for loss, damage, or suffering
examples: The insurance company will recompense you for the stolen items
How can we recompense them for all their time and effort

definitions: restore friendly relations between people who have argued or become enemies
make two different ideas, facts, or situations agree or exist together without problems
examples: The counselor helped the couple reconcile after their big argument
The two brothers finally reconciled after years of not speaking
It's hard to reconcile his gentle manner with his violent past
The accountant needs to reconcile the bank statements with company records

definitions: take control of a place or territory again by force after losing it
examples: The king planned to reconquer the lands taken by enemy forces
Spain tried to reconquer its former colonies in South America

definitions: think again about a decision or opinion and possibly change it after more thought
examples: Please reconsider your decision to quit your job so suddenly
The committee will reconsider the proposal at next month's meeting

definitions: form or create something again in a different way to restore it
add water or another liquid to dried food to return it to its original state
examples: The government reconstituted the committee with new members
They plan to reconstitute the company under new management
Reconstitute the powdered milk by adding warm water and stirring
The dried soup reconstitutes quickly when you add boiling water

definitions: build something again that has been damaged or destroyed
use evidence to work out what happened in the past or how something was
examples: Workers will reconstruct the bridge destroyed in the earthquake
The city plans to reconstruct several historic buildings
Police tried to reconstruct the crime using witness statements
Archaeologists reconstruct ancient civilizations from artifacts and ruins

definitions: tell someone about something that happened by describing events in the order they occurred
count votes again in an election to check if the first result was correct
examples: She recounted her adventures traveling through Asia
The witness recounted exactly what he saw that night
They demanded a recount after the close election results
Officials will recount all ballots cast in the disputed districts

definitions: get back money that you have spent or lost through subsequent profits or payments
examples: The company hopes to recoup its investment within three years
She worked overtime to recoup the money lost during illness

definitions: make something exist or happen again in a similar way
enjoy yourself through relaxing activities done for pleasure in free time
examples: The museum recreated a Victorian street with authentic details
Scientists are trying to recreate conditions from early Earth
The family recreates together at the lake every summer weekend
Many people recreate by hiking in the nearby mountains

definitions: put right something that is wrong or inaccurate by changing or adjusting it
examples: The company quickly rectified the billing error on my account
We need to rectify this misunderstanding before it gets worse

definitions: get better and regain strength or health after being ill, injured, or very tired
examples: She needs several weeks to recuperate after her major surgery
Athletes recuperate in ice baths after intense training sessions

definitions: happen again, especially at regular intervals or in a pattern
examples: Her migraines recur every few weeks despite taking medication
The same technical problem recurs whenever we update the software

definitions: remove yourself from a legal case as a judge or lawyer due to potential bias
examples: The judge had to recuse herself because she knew the defendant
Lawyers must recuse themselves if they have conflicts of interest

definitions: treat waste materials so they can be used again to make new products
use the same ideas, methods, or materials again in a different context
examples: We recycle all our glass bottles and aluminum cans weekly
The factory recycles plastic waste into new packaging materials
Hollywood tends to recycle the same plot ideas repeatedly
She recycled her old presentation for the new client meeting

definitions: make something red or become red in color, often from embarrassment or heat
examples: Her cheeks reddened when everyone started clapping for her
The sunset reddened the sky with beautiful orange and pink colors

definitions: save someone from sin or evil according to religious belief
exchange something like a coupon or points for money, goods, or services
examples: Christians believe Jesus came to redeem humanity from sin
He worked hard to redeem himself after his past mistakes
You can redeem these coupons at any participating store
She redeemed her airline miles for a free flight home

definitions: change the meaning or nature of something by giving it a new definition
examples: The internet has redefined how people communicate and do business
We need to redefine our goals for the next quarter

definitions: move troops, employees, or resources to a new place or for a new purpose
examples: The company will redeploy staff from closed stores to busier locations
Military commanders redeployed troops to defend the eastern border

definitions: change the design or structure of something to improve it or make it different
examples: They hired experts to redesign their website for better user experience
The engineer had to redesign the part to fix the safety issue

definitions: build new buildings or improve an area that was previously developed but has declined
examples: The city plans to redevelop the old industrial district into housing
Investors want to redevelop the abandoned shopping mall

definitions: send someone or something to a different place or along a different route
examples: The receptionist will redirect your call to the correct department
Traffic was redirected away from the accident scene

definitions: find something again that was lost, forgotten, or ignored for a long time
examples: She rediscovered her love for painting after retiring from work
Archaeologists rediscovered the ancient temple buried under sand

definitions: share or spread something out again among people in a different way
examples: The government plans to redistribute wealth through new tax policies
Teachers redistribute classroom supplies to ensure everyone has enough

definitions: refuse loans or services to people in certain areas based on race or income
mark the maximum safe limit on a gauge or the maximum engine speed
examples: Banks were caught redlining minority neighborhoods in the 1960s
It's illegal to redline communities based on racial demographics
Don't redline the engine or you might cause serious damage
The temperature gauge was approaching the redline danger zone

definitions: do something again, especially because it was not done correctly the first time
examples: The teacher asked him to redo his homework with neater handwriting
We had to redo the entire bathroom after finding water damage

definitions: make a sail smaller by rolling or folding part of it to reduce wind exposure
examples: The captain ordered the crew to reef the sails before the storm
Sailors must know how to reef quickly in dangerous weather

definitions: wind something like fishing line or film onto a circular device called a reel
walk or move unsteadily as if about to fall, often from shock or dizziness
examples: He slowly reeled in the fishing line hoping for a big catch
The projectionist had to reel the old film carefully
She reeled backward when she heard the shocking news
The boxer reeled from the powerful punch to his head

definitions: start something again or bring it back into existence after it has ended
examples: The countries worked to reestablish diplomatic relations after the war
She hopes to reestablish contact with her childhood friends

definitions: think about or examine something again to see if your opinion should change
examples: The doctor will reevaluate your condition after two weeks of treatment
It's time to reevaluate our marketing strategy for better results

definitions: act as an official who watches a game to ensure rules are followed fairly
examples: She referees youth soccer games every Saturday morning
Who will referee the championship match next week

definitions: fill a container again after it has been emptied
examples: Please refill my coffee cup when you get a chance
The nurse will refill your prescription for another month

definitions: replace an existing loan with a new loan that has different terms
examples: They decided to refinance their mortgage to get a lower interest rate
Many homeowners refinance when rates drop significantly

definitions: remove unwanted substances from something to make it pure
improve something by making small changes to make it more accurate or effective
examples: The factory refines crude oil into gasoline and other products
They refine sugar by removing impurities and coloring
She continues to refine her presentation skills through practice
Engineers refine the design based on testing results

definitions: repair and provide new equipment or parts to a ship, building, or machine
examples: The navy will refit the destroyer with new radar systems
They plan to refit the old factory as modern office space

definitions: direct your attention or efforts to something different or adjust focus again
examples: The company needs to refocus on customer service quality
Take a break and then refocus on finishing your assignment
